BEIRUT: One wounded Syrian man died Friday soon after crossing into the east Lebanon town of Joura in the Bekaa as the Syrian army tightened security measures along the border.
The security measures by the Syrian army appear to be aimed at halting Syrian fleeing the unrest in their home country.
Heavy fire could be heard coming from the Syrian villages of Jousieh and al-Quseir.
Meanwhile, the Lebanese Army maintained its security measures and patrols along the border.
Lebanonâ€™s eastern border has been under the spotlight following several failed arms smuggling operations and the arrest of a number of people trading arms and smuggling weapons into Syria.
On Wednesday, the Lebanese Army seized two truckloads of weapons in Joura, the latest in a series of that have caused panic in the area.
A security source, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Daily Star that the weapons were concealed in two Cold-storage trucks parked on a back road in Masharih al-Qaa.
Earlier this week, the army arrested 10 armed Lebanese and Syrian men in Joura. They were driving vehicles loaded with weapons including mortar shells, rocket-Propelled grenades and military uniforms. Those arrested were interrogated by army intelligence in Ablah in the Bekaa and the security source said they were referred to the Armyâ€™s Beirut headquarters Thursday.
